contents:
Introductory BlurbBecause of time, I had to remove the code itself from this HTML document. I think I learned a solid lesson about choosing a proper Hugo Theme that will be best for my purposes. I really like the persian theme but it does not appear to be good for showing .rmd chunks for translating how the ggplot was generated below.
I appreciate this lesson a great deal because I think this will be an extremely valuable way to present my CV and visualizations that I have made for lab and publications.
I'll just be sure to pick a better theme for my needs next time : )
Canadian TurbineThese data will be loaded in directly to avoid any loading errors from personal machines, and all functions will be from the tidyverse. This is the Candian Wind Turbine Data (https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/blob/master/data/2020/2020-10-27/readme.md) from the Tidy Tuesday R dataset.
The snapshot below contains the variable informaion:
Candian Wind Turbine Dataset Variable Description
Load the DataThis looked better without the chunk but I thought the code was appropriate for the class. I would not include this chunk if this was not for course review.
# loading the csv directly from the sitewind_turbine <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/master/data/2020/2020-10-27/wind-turbine.csv')## Parsed with column specification:## cols(## objectid = col_double(),## province_territory = col_character(),## project_name = col_character(),## total_project_capacity_mw = col_double(),## turbine_identifier = col_character(),## turbine_number_in_project = col_character(),## turbine_rated_capacity_k_w = col_double(),## rotor_diameter_m = col_double(),## hub_height_m = col_double(),## manufacturer = col_character(),## model = col_character(),## commissioning_date = col_character(),## latitude = col_double(),## longitude = col_double(),## notes = col_character()## )Tidy the DataThis looked better without the chunk but I thought the code was appropriate for the class. I would not include this chunk if this was not for course review.
# make characters to factors for easier groupingwind_turbine <- wind_turbine %>%mutate_if(is.character,as.factor)#glimpse(wind_turbine) # there are almost 7000 turbines in this data, across 12 Canadian providences# removing unwated variablesselected_wind_turbines <- wind_turbine %>%select(-notes,-longitude,-latitude,-turbine_identifier,-turbine_number_in_project)# creating arbitrary but even categoriesselected_wind_turbines <- selected_wind_turbines %>% mutate(capacity_category = ntile(turbine_rated_capacity_k_w, 6))# creating ratings variableselected_wind_turbines <- selected_wind_turbines %>%mutate(capacity_rating = case_when(capacity_category == 1 ~ "low",capacity_category == 2 ~ "below_average",capacity_category == 3 ~ "average",capacity_category == 4 ~ "above_average",capacity_category == 5 ~ "high"))# assigning levels to new variable -## makes visualizaions easier laer onselected_wind_turbines$capacity_rating <- factor(selected_wind_turbines$capacity_rating,levels = c("low","below_average","average","above_average","high"))#view#glimpse(selected_wind_turbines)Plotting the dataThis looked better without the chunk but I thought the code was appropriate for the class. I would not include this chunk if this was not for course review.
The ggplot colors are loosely based on the uniforms the Portland Trailblazers were wearing on 5/11/21 when they played the Houston Rockets.
# plotting the dataselected_wind_turbines %>%filter(!capacity_rating == "NA") %>%filter(!province_territory %in% c("Manitoba", # removing those with low turbines"Northwest Territories","Newfoundland and Labrador","Yukon","New Brunswick")) %>%ggplot(aes(x=hub_height_m,y=rotor_diameter_m,size=total_project_capacity_mw),alpha = .8) +geom_jitter(aes(color=capacity_rating)) +theme_dark() +theme(plot.background = element_rect(fill = "dimgrey")) +theme(axis.text = element_text(colour = "black",face = "bold")) +guides(size = FALSE) +theme(legend.background = (element_rect(fill = "grey71"))) +scale_color_brewer(palette="Set3") +scale_size(range = c(0, 10)) +labs(x="Turbine Height (m)",y="Rotor Diameter (m)",color = "Ranking",title = "Candian Turbine Output Capacity",subtitle = "Relative to Turbine Height and Weight") +theme(axis.title.x = element_text(size=14, face="bold", colour = "black")) +theme(axis.title.y = element_text(size=14, face="bold", colour = "black"))
title: examples

contents:
“And I knew exactly what to do. But in a much more real sense, I had no idea what to do.” – Michael Scott.
 Publications
Articles
Parr, Lisa A., Thomas Mitchell, and Erin Hecht. Intranasal oxytocin in rhesus monkeys alters brain networks that detect social salience and reward. American journal of primatology 80.10 (2018): e22915.
Eric Feczko, TA Mitchell, Hasse Walum, Jenna M. Brooks, Thomas R. Heitz, Larry J. Young, Lisa A. Parr. Establishing the reliability of rhesus macaque social network assessment from video observations. Animal Behaviour, 115-123. September, 2015.
Abstracts
Maternal Western Style Diet Perturbs Fetal Neurodevelopment and Alters Postnatal Outcomes. AJ Mitchell, Jacqueline R. Thompson, Madison DeCapo, Jennifer L. Bagley, Eric Feczko, Damien A. Fair, Elinor L. Sullivan Analysis of Behavioral Association International (ABAI) 2020 (virtual)
Julian S.B. Ramirez, Alice M. Graham, Elina Thomas, Robert Hermosillo, Jennifer Y. Zhu, Darrick Sturgeon, Emma Schifsky, Jacqueline R. Thompson, Jennifer L. Bagley, Samantha Papadakis, Muhammed Bah, AJ Mitchell, Eric Feczko, Elinor L. Sullivan, Damien A. Fair. Differential macaque cortical thickness development in the light of maternal IL-6 and diet (Poster). Organization for Human Brain Mapping (OHBM) Conference, Rome, Italy (2019).
Jacqueline R Thompson, AJ Mitchell, Samantha Papadakis, Damien A Fair, Elinor L Sullivan, 2019, Probing the Diversity of Raphe Serotonergic Nuclei: The Impact of Perinatal Western-Style Diet (Poster), Oregon Society for Neuroscience, Portland, Oregon (2019).
Eric Feczko & Thomas AJ Mitchell, Hasse Walum, Thomas R. Heitz, Lisa A. Parr. Reliability of Macaque Social Networks Using Video (Poster). Society for Social Neuroscience Conference, Washington, DC (2014).
Book Chapters
The Influence of Maternal High Fat Diet Consumption on Neurobehavioral Development AJ Mitchell, Matthew Selby, and Elinor L Sullivan The Neuroscience of Development (2020 - in publication)
title: Publications

contents:
My Research I am in the lab of Dr. Elinor Sullivan and co-mentored by Dr. Damien Fair at the Universtiy of Minnesota.
My research focuses on understanding the effects of the overconsumption of a high-fat diet during pregnancy. Specifically, my work is dedicated to understanding how this effects fetal neurodevelopment and social outcomes.
 I focus on understanding how diet and obesity impact the immune response during pregnancy, and then how these changes related to offspring social outcomes.
title: Research
